title: Podcast Pearls: Building Your Business, Finding a Balance
text:
Text size

In addition to being a veteran advisor coach, Wisconsin-based Steve Sanduski is also a prolific writer and podcaster. His “Between Now and Success” podcast interviews with smart folks in and around the wealth management industry focus, in Steve’s words, on the intersection of business, investing and life.

We asked Steve to share a few of the most impactful ideas he’s taken from his recent podcasts, in the form of a Q&A, and he’s provided plenty of food for thought.

Q: Describe one compelling idea you’ve learned recently from a podcast guest about growing a practice.

A: No coach would ever put their players on the field without a playbook, without a game plan to win the game. Yet, so many advisors rely on passive referrals or an inconsistent marketing strategy to try and generate new business.

Advisors Dennis Morton and Kathryn Brown of Morton Brown Family Wealth took a page from the sports world and created a business development playbook that diagrams, organizes, and tracks the results of their lead to client business development process.

“The playbook lays out in a continuum, how someone goes from being a cold or warm name, through all of the stages, steps, tools, and resources that lead to them becoming a client,” said Dennis.

And the playbook is embedded as CRM workflows that fire automatically when a new step in the playbook is reached, added Kathryn. The combination of the playbook and automation ensures no leads slip through the cracks. Listen to the podcast.

Q: Describe one compelling idea you’ve learned recently about better serving clients.

A: I’ve never met a client that wants to be “scaled,“ have you? Scaling your business involves using technology to be fast and efficient. But Ross Levin, co-founder of Accredited Investor, says excelling in “the slow things is something that is really important, because that’s the part that technology, I don’t believe, can overcome.”

The slow things are the conversations and the life changes, and being on the front end of dealing with people through their day-to-day existence and through all the major things that go on in their life, said Ross.

There’s no technology that will enable two humans to increase the speed at which they’re having an in-depth conversation. Your advantage over the “fast” players like robo-advisors is to excel at these slow things and staff and price your services accordingly. Listen to the podcast.

Q: Describe one compelling idea a guest shared recently about balancing work and personal life/ health.

A: Richard Branson famously said, “I don’t think of work as work and play as play, it’s all living. And I’ve found that the most successful people follow Branson’s thinking and aim for work-life integration, not work-life balance.

Twenty-year Navy SEAL veteran David Sears told me work-life balance is not two scales that you add one weight to and, “Ooh, I spent eight hours at work, now I have to spend eight hours of play. That’s not how it works. I’m saying it’s more of a yin and yang thing. Your work and play are inter-meshed. When you play, you gain this diversity of experiences in different things that fire off connections that you don’t know exist. You won’t know what you’re going to connect until you get outside of your work.” Listen to the podcast.

Steve Sanduski, CFP, is the founder of Belay Advisor; the CEO of ROL Advisor, a discovery process technology system; a New York Times bestselling author; host of the Between Now and Success podcast and a financial advisor business coach.
description: Veteran advisor coach Steve Sanduski shares some of the best ideas from his recent podcast guests.
